sen.j: 武家役（ぶけやく）とは、鎌倉幕府・室町幕府が賦課した課税の総称である。
sen.e: Bukeyaku was a general term for taxation imposed by Kamakura and Muromachi bakufu.

sen.j: 大きな分類として2つの方法がある。

sen.j: まず1つは賦課の主体によるものである。
sen.e: The one is categorization based on who had the initiative on imposing the taxation.

sen.j: 朝廷が幕府に対して命じられた公役を御家人・守護・地頭などに転嫁するものと、幕府そのものの運営維持のために幕府が独自に賦課したものという考えである。
sen.e: According to this point of view, there were public services ordered by the Imperial court to the bakufu which were shifted onto Gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods), Shugo and Jito (military governor and estate steward), and taxes and labors imposed independently by the bakufu in order to operate and maintain itself.

sen.e: There were taxes and labors borne by Gokenin, Shugo and Jito as a part of their obligations to the bakufu because they had a relationship of favor and service with the bakufu.

sen.e: There were other taxes and labors imposed on ordinary people, temples, shrines and shoen (manor in medieval Japan) in the same relationship with the bakufu in the form of tansen (a kind of provisional tax in medieval Japan) and munabetsu-sen, both of which had the aspect of Ikkoku heikinyaku (taxes and labor uniformly imposed on shoen (manor) and kokugaryo (provincial land) in a province).

sen.e: The bukeyaku imposed by the Kamakura bakufu was called Kanto-kuji (public duties).

sen.e: It was imposed on Gokenin based on size of koden (field administered directly by a ruler) in their shoryo (territories) which was registered on a cadaster called Ota-bumi.

sen.e: After the Mongol invasion attempts against Japan, these burdens became intolerable, and the shifting of the burdens onto peasants aroused the bitterest opposition among them.

sen.e: The bukeyaku by the Muromachi bakufu was mainly imposed on Shugo daimyo (Japanese territorial lord as provincial constable) and the citizens of Kyoto.
